---
title: "@microviz/themes"
slug: themes
---

Base CSS tokens and layered defaults (`@layer microviz`) for styling microviz output.

## Files

- `@microviz/themes/tokens.css`: token variables only (`--mv-*`).
- `@microviz/themes/base.css`: tokens + default class styles (wrapped in `@layer microviz`).
- `@microviz/themes/variants.css`: optional theme presets (Carbon-inspired `white/g10/g90/g100`).

## Theme presets

Import `variants.css`, then apply either a class or a `data-mv-theme` attribute:

```ts
import "@microviz/themes/base.css";
import "@microviz/themes/variants.css";
```

```html
<div class="mv-theme-g90 rounded-md p-2">
  <microviz-sparkline data="[6,10,7,12,9,14]"></microviz-sparkline>
</div>

<div data-mv-theme="g10" class="rounded-md p-2">
  <microviz-sparkline data="[6,10,7,12,9,14]"></microviz-sparkline>
</div>
```

To keep the preset palette but render on a transparent surface (no preset background), add `data-mv-bg="transparent"`:

```html
<div data-mv-theme="g100" data-mv-bg="transparent" class="rounded-md p-2">
  <microviz-sparkline data="[6,10,7,12,9,14]"></microviz-sparkline>
</div>
```

## What are `white/g10/g90/g100`?

These names are **Carbon-inspired surface steps** (a convenient shared vocabulary for “what background is this chart sitting on?”).

In microviz, presets are just bundles of CSS variables (set by `variants.css`) for a coherent chart surface:

- `--mv-bg`: surface background
- `--mv-fg`, `--mv-muted`, `--mv-grid`: text + grid contrast tokens
- `--mv-series-*`: chart palette (notably adjusted in `g90`/`g100` for readability)

Preset meanings:

- `white`: pure white surface
- `g10`: subtle light-gray surface (great for cards on a white page)
- `g90`: dark-gray surface
- `g100`: near-black surface

## Presets vs. color scheme (dark mode)

Your app’s color scheme (`prefers-color-scheme`, or framework “dark mode”) is about the **surrounding UI**.
Microviz presets are about the **chart surface + token palette**.

They are intentionally decoupled: you can render a `g10` chart inside a dark UI, or a `g100` chart on a light page, if that matches the host surface.

If you want them to track each other, treat it as an app decision (there is no CSS “auto” preset). For example:

```ts
const theme = window.matchMedia("(prefers-color-scheme: dark)").matches
  ? "g100"
  : "white";
document.documentElement.dataset.mvTheme = theme;
```
